Table 2 Catalyst T (oC) P (MPa) WHSV (mL/(gcat·h)) XCO2 (%) Selectivity (%) Ref Ni@MOF-5 280 0.1 7500 47.2 100 [9] Ni/Al2O3 300 0.1 15000 45.0 100 [45] Ni/Si 300 0.1 15000 27.0 94.5 [46] Ni/Ca/Si 300 0.1 15000 37.2 97.2 [46] Ni/Ba/Si 300 0.1 1000 38.3 97.4 [46] Co/meso-SiO2 300 0.1 22000 43.5 78.7 [47] Co-5H2/Ar 300 0.1 45,000 48.5 97.1 This work Controllable preparation of ZIF-67 derived catalyst for CO2 methanation Tingting Zhao 1 Yajun Hui 1 Niamatullah Zhenhua Li ⁎ Key Lab for Green Chemical Technology of Ministry of Education, School of Chemical Engineering and Technology, Collaborative Innovation Center of Chemical Science and Engineering (Tianjin), Tianjin University, Tianjin, 300072, China Key Lab for Green Chemical Technology of Ministry of Education School of Chemical Engineering and Technology Collaborative Innovation Center of Chemical Science and Engineering (Tianjin) Tianjin University Tianjin 300072 China ⁎ Corresponding author at: School of Chemical Engineering and Technology, Tianjin University, Weijin Road 92, Tianjin, 300072, China. School of Chemical Engineering and Technology Tianjin University Weijin Road 92 Tianjin 300072 China 1 These authors contributed equally. Graphical abstract A mild method for preparing Co catalysts by carbonizing ZIF-67 under an H2/Ar atmosphere is proposed for CO2 methanation. A mild method for preparing an N-doped Co catalyst by carbonizing ZIF-67 under the mixture of an H2/Ar atmosphere is proposed for CO2 methanation. Graphitic carbon can be successfully obtained even at 500 °C when an appropriate amount of hydrogen appears in the carbonization atmosphere. The presence of graphitic carbon heightens the thermal stability of the catalyst. Additionally, the existence of H2 promotes the formation of oxygen vacancies and enhances the electron transfer between Co and carbon matrix. The transformation of N species is correlated with H2 content in the H2/Ar gas mixture. The CO2 conversion shows a consistent tendency with the relative proportion of graphitized-N. Although the extra reduction process is omitted during the catalytic test, the as-prepared Co-5H2/Ar catalyst achieved a CO2 conversion of 48.5% under 300 °C, 45,000 mL g−1 h−1 WHSV and 0.1 MPa. Keywords ZIF-67 Hydrogen Graphitic carbon Oxygen vacancies Graphitized-N 1 Introduction The burning of fossil fuels has brought unprecedented development to human society but correspondingly results in excessive emissions of carbon dioxide. As reported, the atmospheric CO2 concentration reached up to 400 ppm in 2014, almost 1.5 times higher than that at the beginning of the industrial revolution [1]. With high certainty, the excessive emissions of carbon dioxide have caused global warming, which is threatening our society. In this respect, converting CO2 into valuable chemicals raises great interest all over the world. One of the effective ways to convert CO2 is CO2 methanation. It has potential applications in the integration with gas processing. The low-quality syngas produced by biomass gasification or the waste mixture containing large amounts of CO2 can be upgraded by this reaction, which will not only reduce carbon dioxide emission but also yield value-added product. For CO2 methanation reaction, Ni-based catalysts have long been the main research object. However, Zhou et al. [2] stated that Co/SiO2 exhibited superior property for CO2 hydrogenation than Ni/SiO2 catalyst. Likewise, Liu et al. [3] reported that the ordered mesoporous Co/SiO2 catalyst expressed optimal catalytic activity in CO2 hydrogenation. Nevertheless, the research on Co-based catalyst for CO2 methanation is of deficiency so far yet. Metal organic frameworks (MOFs) are porous coordination polymer assembling the respective beneficial characteristics of inorganic and organic components and also frequently show unique properties for a simple component [4,5]. Application of MOFs supported materials is also reported for CO2 conversion [6–9] whereas the highly instability of MOFs restricts its high-temperature activity. As a matter of fact, MOFs derived carbon porous materials alternatively provide us a new clue [10,11]. The dense carbon matrix formed during the carbonization process can effectively anchor the metal particles thus prevent sintering. For instance, Li et al. [12] reported ZIF-67 templated catalyst with 52.5% CO2 conversion and 99.2% CH4 selectivity at 270 °C and 3 MPa. Liu et al. [13] pyrolyzed Fe-MIL-88B to obtain 46.0% CO2 conversion at 400 °C and 3 MPa. As known, the combination of basic N species into catalyst will strengthen the adsorption/absorption capability for acidic gases [14,15]. Progress on advanced capture of CO2 by exploiting N-doped carbons has been achieved in recent years [16–19]. Among all the MOFs, ZIF-67 is simple in preparation and low in cost. The composition of N species can eliminate the N-doping process. Therefore, the use of ZIF-67 templated catalyst is studied for the catalytic test of CO2 methanation in this work. Beyond that, the catalytic effect of transition metals embedded in the skeleton of ZIF-67 can facilitate the formation of graphitic carbon during carbonization [20]. Some researchers innovatively introduced H2 to promote the reduction of transition metals and sequentially facilitate the mass production of carbon nanotubes [21]. Aijaz et al. [22] pyrolyzed ZIF-67 in H2 atmosphere at 800 °C to obtain CNT-grafted carbon polyhedra. Chen et al. [23] synthesized hierarchical tubular structures by carbonizing ZIF-67 in Ar/H2 at 750 °C. However, high carbonization temperatures may cause agglomeration of metal particles, resulting in a great loss in the metal specific surface area [24]. Herein, a mild strategy is recommended in this paper to acquire an N-doped Co-based catalyst by annealing ZIF-67 at low temperature (500 °C) under the mixture of the H2/Ar atmosphere. The crystal morphologies and particle size are closely related to the hydrogen content. Therefore, a series of Co-xH2/Ar catalysts (where x represents the volume percentage of hydrogen in the H2/Ar mixture, x = 0, 5, 10, 20) have been prepared to investigate the role of hydrogen content playing in the properties of catalyst and catalytic activity of CO2 methanation. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials Cobalt nitrate hexahydrate, 2-methylimidazole and methanol were purchased from Tianjin Kermel Chemical Reagent Co. Ltd., China. All the chemicals used in this experiment are analytical grade. 2.2 Catalyst preparation 2.2.1 Synthesis of ZIF-67 ZIF-67 was prepared as below: briefly, 0.875 g Co(NO3)2·6H2O was dissolved into 50 mL methanol, then another 50 mL methanol containing 1.973 g 2-methylimidazole was quickly poured into the above-mentioned solution. 5-minutes vigorously stir at room temperature was followed by being kept for 4 h. Afterwards the suspension was collected by 8,000 rpm centrifuging for 5 min, washed with 20 mL methanol 3 times, and then dried overnight at 80 °C in the vacuum oven. 2.2.2 Synthesis of Co-xH2/Ar The as-prepared ZIF-67 was carbonized in a tube furnace from 25 °C to 500 °C with a heating rate of 1 °C/min for 8 h. Pre-substitution was needed by introducing pure Ar to replace the air in the chamber prior to the temperature program. Lately, the mixture of 100 mL/min xH2/Ar gas was introduced to proceed the carbonization process. The obtained catalysts are donated as Co-xH2/Ar. 2.3 Characterization Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) was performed on an X’ Pert Pro diffractometer at 40 kV voltage and 40 mA current with Cu K-alpha radiation (λ = 0.15406 nm). The scanning speed was 0.1°/s over a range of 5°-80°. Field-emission scanning electron microscopy (SEM) was conducted on FESEM, S4800 and high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HR-TEM) was conducted on Tecnai G2 F20. Thermogravimetric analysis (TG) was conducted on a STA449F3 NETZSCH Corp. thermal analyzer from 40 °C to 840 °C at a temperature ramp of 10 °C/min under the atmosphere of air. N2 adsorption-desorption was operated at −196 °C in a Micromeritics Tristar-3000 analyzer. Prior to the measurement, the samples were degassed under an N2 atmosphere at 200 °C for 3 h. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was recorded on Perkin-Elmer PHI 1600 ESCA using Al Ka radiation. The binding energy (BE) was calibrated of C1s at 284.6 eV. Laser Raman spectrum was obtained on a DXR Microscope spectrometer using the 633 nm radiation line from a Spectra-Physics-2020 argon laser. Carbon dioxide temperature programmed desorption (CO2-TPD) and hydrogen temperature programmed desorption analysis (H2-TPD) was carried out by using a Micromeritics AutoChem 2910 instrument. The H2 uptake, Co dispersion (D) and Co metal specific surface area (SCo) were obtained according to the following formulas [25]: D % = 2 V H × N A / V m m × ω × N A / M S C o m 2 / g C o = 2 V H × N A × σ C o m × ω × V m Where VH represents the monolayer adsorption on the catalyst surface of hydrogen, Vm represents the molar volume of hydrogen (22.4 L/mol), NA represents the Avogadro Constant, m represents the mass of the catalyst (g), ω represents the mass fraction of Co, M represents the molar mass of Co (58.9 g/mol), σCo represents the cross sectional area of Co atom. 2.4 Catalytic activity test CO2 methanation proceeds as the following reaction equation: C O 2 + 4 H 2 ↔ C H 4 + 2 H 2 O Δ H 298 0 = − 165 kJ / mol Reverse water-gas shift (RWGS) also proceeds as below: C O 2 + H 2 ↔ CO + H 2 O Δ H 298 0 = 41 kJ / mol CO2 methanation was performed at atmospheric pressure in a fixed-bed reactor which was equipped with a quartz glass tube of 500 mm length, 12 mm outer diameter and 8 mm inner diameter. Before reaction, the reactor was loaded with 0.12 g catalyst and 0.24 g diluted quartz sand. H2 and CO2 were fed with the molar ratio of 4:1 under the reaction temperature from 200 °C to 450 °C. The WHSV was kept at 45,000 mL/(gcat·h). The outlet gas mixture was analyzed online using an Agilent 4890D GC apparatus which was fitted with a TDX-01 column and equipped with a TCD detector, using H2 as the carrier gas. CO2 conversion and CH4 selectivity were calculated by the following formula： X C O 2 ( % ) = F C O 2 in − F C O 2 out F C O 2 in × 100 % S C H 4 ( % ) = F C H 4 in F C O 2 in − F C O 2 out × 100 % Where X and S represent the CO2 conversion and CH4 selectivity, respectively. 3 Results and discussion The fabrication process of the Co-based catalyst is illustrated in Scheme 1 . The as-synthesized ZIF-67 samples show a pure crystallinity and well-defined morphology (Fig. S1). On this basis, the ZIF-67 precursor is subjected to carbonization at 500 °C under the mixture of an H2/Ar atmosphere to get different morphological ZIF-67 self-templated catalysts by varying H2 contents. The crystalline nature was confirmed by XRD analysis. As shown in Fig. 1 a, all the Co-xH2/Ar catalysts present a sharp characteristic peak at 44.3°, belonging to the (111) crystal face of metallic Co. Another two peaks at 51.7° and 75.8°, belonging to the (200) and (220) crystal face of metallic Co [26], respectively, are observed for Co-20H2/Ar, while no such obvious peaks appear for the other catalysts. Also, no characteristic peaks for Co oxides was observed. As reported, the Co ions exist in MOFs always form pure metal NPs during carbonization [27]. Given this, all the catalysts in this work are used directly after carbonization to catalyze CO2 methanation and without further reduction procedure. The intensity of the diffraction peaks augments with the increase of hydrogen content, indicating a gradual growth in the Co crystal size. On the one hand, the existence of hydrogen will etch away amorphous carbon, resulting in a decrease in the anchoring sites of metals and consequently causes the agglomerate of cobalt particles [28,29]. According to Yang et.al. [30], the reaction of carbon and H2 followed equations: (1) H2 be converted to H· (hydrogen radical) (2) H· reacts with carbon to form CH· radical. (1) H 2 → H ⋅ + H (2) H ⋅ + C → CH ⋅ When the fraction of CH˙ radicals was higher than that required by carbonization reaction, the excess CH˙ radicals will be carried away by the gas stream, leading to the consumption of in situ carbon and conversely causing the formation of carbon deficient phase. On the other hand, the decrease of carbon matrix causes more cobalt to be exposed, which will also reflect in the increased XRD peak intensity. N2 adsorption-desorption measurement was performed to investigate the texture properties of the catalysts. As shown in Fig. 1b, Co-xH2/Ar possesses a typical type I and IV adsorption isotherm with a palpable hysteresis loop in the P/P0 range of 0.9–1.0, revealing its remarkable micro-/meso-/macroporous structure. The large-pore structure of Co-0H2/Ar particles arise from the stacking of nanocrystals with smaller sizes. While for Co-5H2/Ar and Co-10H2/Ar samples, the pronounced hysteresis loop in the P/P0 range of 0.45–0.95 indicates the mesoporous nature inside the skeleton. Co-5H2/Ar sample shows a pore diameter of 7.1 nm and a relatively high pore volume of 0.4 nm. The enlarged pore size and pore volume is beneficial for the internal diffusion of reactants as well as products [31]. The specific BET surface area for Co-0H2/Ar is 395.6 m2 g−1, while which is significantly lower in the catalysts carbonized under H2 atmosphere. This is also coincided with the XRD result. Co-20H2/Ar has a specific BET surface area of only 32.8 m2 g−1, owing to the great loss of carbon and nitrogen. The micro structural morphology was characterized by SEM and TEM, shown in Fig. 2 . The catalyst carbonized under pure Ar (i.e. Co-0H2/Ar) atmosphere inherits the well-defined rhombic dodecahedron form with a smooth surface (Fig. 2a1, a2), while the catalysts carbonized under the mix H2/Ar atmosphere suffer morphological damage. For example, the Co-5H2/Ar catalyst became spherical with a much rougher surface (Fig. 2b1, b2). The Co-xH2/Ar catalysts carbonized at higher hydrogen content have more irregular morphologies and obscure boundaries between particle interfaces. As mentioned above, the presence of reducing H2 gas promotes the transformation from ionic Co to metallic Co, which makes it possible to form carbon nanotubes at a very low temperature. The twisted graphitic carbon further leads to the roughness of the catalyst surface. This is also verified by Chen et al. [23] that if pure Ar is used instead of H2/Ar in the carbonization process, graphitic carbon can’t be generated on the catalyst. Clearly, Co-20H2/Ar shows the gradual evolution of crystal morphologies with the co-appearance of block and pea-shaped microstructures (Fig. 2d1, d2), assigning to the carbonized ZIF-67 particles and agglomerate Co nanoparticles with little carbon matrix, respectively. As shown by TEM images (Fig. 2a3-4, b3-4, c3-4, d3-4), no matter what atmosphere is ZIF-67 carbonized, all the Co NPs are homogenously embedded in the carbon matrix. The Co-0H2/Ar catalyst shows a dense carbon matrix and no obvious porous structure is observed. However, the Co-5H2/Ar, Co-10H2/Ar and Co-20H2/Ar catalysts show obvious pore structure and a considerable graphitic carbon on the surface of Co-5H2/Ar and Co-10H2/Ar samples, confirming the feasibility of this method. Particle size statistics (Fig. 3 ) intuitively show the variation of Co particle sizes. The average size of Co nanoparticles for Co-0H2/Ar, Co-5H2/Ar, and Co-10H2/Ar catalysts is 7.1, 11.1, and 14.4 nm, respectively, which is up to 31.7 nm for the Co-20H2/Ar sample. The size distribution range for Co-10H2/Ar is 0–50 nm, while it is 0–180 nm for Co-20H2/Ar. As reported, the catalytic performance of reverse water-gas shift (RWGS) reaction is greatly affected by the particle size of active metals. Larger metal particles or aggregates generally contribute to producing more CH4 [15,32]. In addition, the smaller particle size is more likely to cause agglomeration of metal particles during the reaction, which is disadvantageous for the catalytic reaction. From the subsequent discussion on the catalytic activity, the Co-5H2/Ar catalyst showing the highest methane selectivity is somewhat attributed to its larger particle size. Raman spectroscopy (Fig. 4 a) was performed to determine the degree of graphitization. The typical G bands at 1580 cm−1 and D bands at 1320 cm−1 are associated with the graphitic sp2-carbon and disordered or defect carbon, respectively. The intensity ratio of D to G bands (ID/IG) is obtained for quantitative analysis of the degree of graphitization, which is 0.63, 0.39, 0.52 and 0.64 for Co-0H2/Ar, Co-5H2/Ar, Co-10H2/Ar and Co-20H2/Ar, respectively [26]. The deconvolution of Raman spectra for Co-xH2/Ar catalysts are shown in Fig. S2. The decreased value from Co-0H2/Ar to Co-5H2/Ar and Co-10H2/Ar represents the increased graphitization degree. As evidenced, the increased graphitization degree of the samples is beneficial for high electronic mobility, thereby facilitate the interaction of reactant molecules [33]. However, the value of ID/IG for Co-20H2/Ar is similar with that of Co-0H2/Ar, confirming the importance of proper amount of hydrogen. All the catalysts were characterized by TG analysis under an air atmosphere. During the thermal treatment, Co-xH2/Ar catalysts simultaneously perform two reactions containing the oxidation of metallic cobalt and the oxidation of carbon. The former reaction associates with the increase in the final mass of the catalyst while the latter shows exactly the opposite result. As indicates in Fig. 4b, all the three Co-0H2/Ar, Co-5H2/Ar, and Co-10H2/Ar catalysts present a weight loss following the order: Co-10H2/Ar < Co-5H2/Ar < Co-0H2/Ar. This phenomenon illustrates that the amount of carbon in the catalyst is inversely proportional to the amount of H2 in the carbonation atmosphere, which is in good agreement with XRD and TEM results. Furthermore, due to the minimal carbon content in Co-20H2/Ar catalyst, the oxidation of metallic cobalt dominates, explaining the increase in its weight. Compared with Co-0H2/Ar sample, the carbon oxidation temperature of Co-5H2/Ar and Co-10H2/Ar shift to a higher degree. The offset increases with the increase of hydrogen content, demonstrating the elevated thermal stability of catalysts. This temperature shift is clearly observed in the DTG curves (Fig. S3). The peak of the DTG curves represents the maximum rate point of carbon oxidation. The corresponded temperature of the peak for the Co-0H2/Ar catalyst is 266 °C, while they are 279 °C and 338 °C for Co-5H2/Ar and Co-10H2/Ar respectively, illustrating the gradually increased thermal stability with increased H2 content. It is recognized that, there are many functional groups bonded to the surface of graphitic carbon. These functional groups can form stable chemical bonds with the substrate, making graphitic carbon have higher oxidation resistance and decomposition temperature than amorphous carbon [34]. The presence of carbon nanotubes enhances the thermal stability of the catalyst and maintains the good performance of Co-xH2/Ar catalysts in high-temperature reactions. TG analysis was also used to calculate the loading of Co. From TG results, the Co-xH2/Ar catalysts have a high cobalt loading from approximately 40%˜90% (Table S2). As reported, CO2 molecules possess low energy level orbitals and high electron affinity (38 eV), which will lead to electron acceptance capability [35]. The low first ionization energy (7.81 eV) of CO2 molecules makes it easier for Co NPs to adsorb CO2 by transferring electrons to CO2 molecules to form CO- species [36]. Hence, the homogenous and high-loading Co NPs is beneficial for the adsorption and activation of CO2 molecules. XPS spectra were recorded to elucidate the correlation between the type of N species and the catalytic properties. The survey XPS spectrum (Fig. S4) proves the existence of Co, C, N, and O elements in the Co-xH2/Ar catalysts. The O1s spectra (Fig. 5 ) for Co-0H2/Ar, Co-5H2/Ar and Co-10H2/Ar catalysts show two peaks at about 532 and 530 eV, ascribing to the surface absorbed oxygen (O1) and lattice oxygen (O2) [27,38], respectively. Moreover, no peaks for Co oxides is observed. Specifically, the O1s peaks for Co-5H2/Ar and Co-10H2/Ar catalysts shift all by +0.3 eV, indicting the occurrence of electron transfer phenomena between Co and C matrix [39]. The relative content of O1/O2 for Co-0H2/Ar is 2.74, which rises to 4.30 and 4.65 for Co-5H2/Ar and Co-10H2/Ar, respectively, demonstrating the increase in oxygen vacancies [40]. As report, hydrogen will combine with oxygen embedded in the skeleton to form oxygen vacancies coming into being OH− functionalities [41]. The enriched oxygen vacancies could help to activate CO2 in CO2 methanation process [38]. The peak located at about 530 eV for Co-20H2/Ar catalyst disappears, but it comes out a unique peak at 533.2 eV, attributing to hydroxide species single bonded with carbon (COH) [42]. These results indicate that the H2 content strongly affect the chemical environment of surface species. The N1s XPS spectra for all the catalysts (Fig. 6 a–d) can be deconvoluted into three peaks at 398.5, 399.1, and 401.0 eV, corresponding to pyridinic, pyrrolic, and graphitic N species [43]. The total atomic ratio of N species runs down with the rise of H2 content (Table S2) which is 14.84, 6.55, 3.85, and 0.53 at% in Co-0H2/Ar, Co-5H2/Ar, Co-10H2/Ar, and Co-20H2/Ar catalyst, respectively. For Co-0H2/Ar, Co-5H2/Ar, and Co-10H2/Ar catalysts, graphitic N accounts for the largest proportion in the N dopants. However, the percentage of graphitic N gradually increases from Co-0H2/Ar to Co-5H2/Ar and decrease afterwards with the further increase of H2 content. The basic sites on the catalyst contribute to the adsorption and conversion of reactant CO2 molecules. The loss of N content is not favor for the catalytic activity. CO2-TPD was conducted to corroborate the connection between graphitic N species with CO2 adsorption. As shown in Fig. 7 , The peaks at around 110 °C and 280 °C originate from a weakly basic site and a moderate basic site, respectively, whereas that at 450 °C corresponds to a strong basic site [15]. Among all the catalysts, Co-5H2/Ar catalyst possesses the largest CO2 desorption peak area, indicating its largest CO2 adsorption capacity. This result confirms that graphitic N is the most likely active N site for CO2 methanation. H2-TPD was performed to explore the relation between the dispersion of metal particles and CO2 methanation activity. Considering the maximum reaction temperature of 450 °C, the highest temperature in H2-TPD process was set to 450 °C. The TPD curves below 450 °C are integrated for the calculation of chemisorbed H2 volume. There are three main H2 desorption peaks between50 °C–450 °C, which are attributed to different adsorbed states of hydrogen on the metallic Co surface (Fig. 8 ). The two low-temperature peaks (<350 °C) are attributed to chemisorbed H2 on the metal surface, while the high-temperature desorption peak (>400 °C) is attributed to spillover H2 on the support [37]. The peaks area shows a monotonous decreasing with the increase of H2 content. Correspondingly, the dispersion of the catalyst exhibits the same trend (Table 1 ). However, from the following catalytic test of CO2 methanation, it is known that the CO2 conversion of Co-0H2/Ar is lower than that of Co-5H2/Ar and Co-10H2/Ar. Therefore, the metal dispersion is not the cause of the improvement in catalytic performance in this work. 4 Catalytic activity The catalytic activity of the as-synthesized catalysts was probed by CO2 methanation. As shown in Fig. 9 a, the onset temperature of CO2 methanation over all the catalysts is 200 °C. The CO2 conversion over Co-0H2/Ar, Co-5H2/Ar, and Co-10H2/Ar catalysts rapidly increase with reaction temperature from 200 °C to 450 °C, while Co-20H2/Ar hardly exhibits catalytic activity due to the serious agglomeration of active Co metals. Of all the catalysts, the almost exclusive formation of CH4 is observed. Furthermore, Co-5H2/Ar shows the best catalytic activity over the entire reaction temperature. Particularly at 300 °C, where Co-5H2/Ar shows a significant advantage of 48.5% CO2 conversion and 97.1% CH4 selectivity. The corresponding contents of N species as a function of H2 content is shown in Fig. 9c. The trend of graphitic N proportion versus hydrogen content is same as the CO2 conversion, whereas no such trend is observed for pyridinic N or pyrrolic N species. As reported, the graphitic N-CNTs are more beneficial to the electron transfer, thus enhancing the catalytic performance [44]. The relatively high ratio of graphitic-N in Co-5H2/Ar catalyst circumvents the adverse effects caused by the decline in content, implying the major connection between the species of nitrogen and catalytic activity. Truthfully, the participation of hydrogen during the carbonization process results in the increase in the loading of active metal cobalt. This will also contribute to the promotion of catalytic performance. However, the increase in the loading is accompanied by the agglomeration of active metals, unfavorable for the catalytic activity. By comparing the activity data of Co-5H2/Ar and Co-10H2/Ar samples, it can be seen that the CO2 conversion of Co-5H2/Ar is much higher than that of Co-10H2/Ar sample, indicating that the increase in loading may not be the primary reason for the highest activity of Co-5H2/Ar. The synergistic effect of the increased thermal stability, the formation of oxygen vacancies, as well as the highest amount of graphitized-N species, all contributed to the highest CO2 methanation activity for the Co-5H2/Ar catalyst. Additionally, compared with other MOFs-derived or conventional catalysts previously reported, Co-5H2/Ar shows a competitive activity under atmospheric pressure (Table 2 ). Stability test was conducted at reaction temperature 300 °C for the Co-5H2/Ar catalyst and the results are shown in Fig. 10 . It is observed that CO2 conversion shows a slight decrease from 48.5% to 43.1% after 140 h run and CH4 selectivity decreased from 97.1% to 89.2%. It is deduced that the Co-5H2/Ar catalyst has some change during reaction process. For MOF-derived catalyst, its thermal stability is always a problem to limit its further application. Therefore, continued studies need to be addressed to improve the stability of MOF-derived catalysts. 5 Conclusion In summary, we have demonstrated a mild method for fabrication of N-doped Co-based catalyst assembles with graphitic carbon. The synthesis involves the assembly of metal nodes and organic frameworks and then the carbonization of ZIF-67 under an H2/Ar atmosphere. Different H2 content has a great impact on the microscopic morphology of the catalyst. Based on the characteristic analysis, the proper amount of hydrogen contributes to the formation of graphitic carbon and oxygen vacancies. It also has a correlation with the transformation of different N species. The CO2 methanation performance shows a consistent tendency with the relative amount of graphitized-N. Here, a promising method for the modulation of catalyst morphology has been recommended, which will be feasible for other applications. Appendix A Supplementary data Supplementary material related to this article can be found, in the online version, at doi:https://doi.org/10.1016/j.mcat.2019.110421. coredata.dc:description: A mild method for preparing an N-doped Co catalyst by carbonizing ZIF-67 under the mixture of an H2/Ar atmosphere is proposed for CO2 methanation. Graphitic carbon can be successfully obtained even at 500 °C when an appropriate amount of hydrogen appears in the carbonization atmosphere. The presence of graphitic carbon heightens the thermal stability of the catalyst. Additionally, the existence of H2 promotes the formation of oxygen vacancies and enhances the electron transfer between Co and carbon matrix. The transformation of N species is correlated with H2 content in the H2/Ar gas mixture. The CO2 conversion shows a consistent tendency with the relative proportion of graphitized-N. Although the extra reduction process is omitted during the catalytic test, the as-prepared Co-5H2/Ar catalyst achieved a CO2 conversion of 48.5% under 300 °C, 45,000 mL g−1 h−1 WHSV and 0.1 MPa.
coredata.dc:title: Controllable preparation of ZIF-67 derived catalyst for CO2 methanation
